description: From Latin porphyro + genitus  +‎ -ism, from Ancient Greek [Term?] (“purple”) + [Term?] (“to be born”).

entries.meaning: (rare) The principle of succession in royal families, especially among the Eastern Roman emperors, by which a younger son, if born after the accession of his father to the throne, was preferred to an elder son who was not so born.
examples: The doctrine of Porphyrogenitism, congenial to popular sentiment, and not without some foundation in principle, prevailed influentially and widely in many countries.
